articles.headline: Outside Hollywood Studios, Writers Make Their Case
articles.snippet: Those in picket lines at the headquarters of companies like Netflix were critical of working conditions that have become routine in the streaming era.
articles.abstract: Those in picket lines at the headquarters of companies like Netflix were critical of working conditions that have become routine in the streaming era.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ellen Stutzman, a senior Writers Guild of America official, stood on a battered patch of grass outside Netflix headquarters in Los Angeles. She was calm — remarkably so, given the wild scene unfolding around her, and the role she had played in its creation.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Nicole Sperling

articles.headline: Moscow Claims Explosions Above the Kremlin Were an Attempt to Kill Putin
articles.snippet: Russia said Ukraine had launched a drone attack, which Kyiv vehemently denied, accusing Russia of manufacturing a pretext for escalation.
articles.abstract: Russia said Ukraine had launched a drone attack, which Kyiv vehemently denied, accusing Russia of manufacturing a pretext for escalation.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a pair of explosions above the Kremlin early Wednesday, Russia accused Ukraine of trying to assassinate President Vladimir V. Putin with a drone attack, but Kyiv denied any involvement in an incident that could raise the already-high stakes in Europe’s biggest conflict since World War II.
articles.byline: By Anton Troianovski and Haley Willis

articles.headline: White House Pushes Tech C.E.O.s to Limit Risks of A.I.
articles.snippet: In the White House’s first gathering of A.I. companies, Vice President Kamala Harris told the leaders of major tech companies they had a “moral” obligation to keep products safe.
articles.abstract: In the White House’s first gathering of A.I. companies, Vice President Kamala Harris told the leaders of major tech companies they had a “moral” obligation to keep products safe.
articles.lead_paragraph: The White House on Thursday pushed Silicon Valley chief executives to limit the risks of artificial intelligence, in the administration’s most visible effort to confront rising questions and calls to regulate the rapidly advancing technology.

articles.headline: Even as China Reopens, Security Visits Spook Foreign Businesses
articles.snippet: Fears are growing that the Communist Party’s increasing focus on control over information about markets and companies is behind the questioning of firms.
articles.abstract: Fears are growing that the Communist Party’s increasing focus on control over information about markets and companies is behind the questioning of firms.
articles.lead_paragraph: With China’s pandemic restrictions dismantled and its leaders wooing executives flying into the country again, this was supposed to be a springtime of renewed investor confidence in the world’s second-biggest economy.
articles.byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi, Chris Buckley and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Why China’s Censors Are Deleting Videos About Poverty
articles.snippet: Xi Jinping says he has defeated poverty, but discussion of economic struggle is taboo, scrubbed from the internet and banished from the news.
articles.abstract: Xi Jinping says he has defeated poverty, but discussion of economic struggle is taboo, scrubbed from the internet and banished from the news.
articles.lead_paragraph: A heartbreaking video of a retiree that showed what groceries she could buy with 100 yuan, or $14.50 — roughly her monthly pension and sole source of income — went viral on the Chinese internet. The video was deleted.

articles.headline: One Family Has Spearheaded Montana’s Unflinching Conservatism
articles.snippet: Three members of the Regier family now hold leadership positions in the Montana Legislature as the state’s conservative shift has left even some Republicans wary.
articles.abstract: Three members of the Regier family now hold leadership positions in the Montana Legislature as the state’s conservative shift has left even some Republicans wary.
articles.lead_paragraph: KALISPELL, Mont. — During a legislative hearing in 2011 that was a prelude to Montana’s debates on abortion, State Representative Keith Regier displayed an image of a cow and made the argument that cattle were more valuable when pregnant.
articles.byline: By Mike Baker and Jacey Fortin

articles.headline: Earthquake-Proof, Not Corruption-Proof: Turkey’s Needless Deaths
articles.snippet: Turkish families got wealthy off a construction system rife with patronage. A Times investigation reveals just how fatally shaky that system was.
articles.abstract: Turkish families got wealthy off a construction system rife with patronage. A Times investigation reveals just how fatally shaky that system was.
articles.lead_paragraph: The building began convulsing at 4:17 a.m. Firat Yayla was awake in bed, scrolling through videos on his phone. His mother was asleep down the hall.
articles.byline: By Ceylan Yeginsu, Rebecca R. Ruiz and Nimet Kirac

articles.headline: Britain’s Economy Needs a Pick-Me-Up. Is the Coronation Enough?
articles.snippet: Caught between slow growth and high inflation, businesses are hoping King Charles’s coronation will bolster consumer confidence enough to last more than just one weekend.
articles.abstract: Caught between slow growth and high inflation, businesses are hoping King Charles’s coronation will bolster consumer confidence enough to last more than just one weekend.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dawn Anchor, who runs a pub in the village of Kings Worthy, about 60 miles southwest of London, has everything she needs: reams of red, white and blue bunting, mini Union Jack flags and a life-size cardboard cutout of King Charles III.
